title: Rational number
summary:
In mathematics, a rational number is a number that can be expressed as the quotient or fraction p/q of two integers, a numerator p and a non-zero denominator q.[1] For example, ‚àí3/7 is a rational number, as is every integer (e.g. 5 = 5/1). The set of all rational numbers, also referred to as "the rationals",[2] the field of rationals[3] or the field of rational numbers is usually denoted by a boldface Q (or blackboard bold 
  
    
      
        
          Q
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} }
  
, Unicode U+1D410 ùêê MATHEMATICAL BOLD CAPITAL Q or U+211A ‚Ñö DOUBLE-STRUCK CAPITAL Q);[4] it was thus denoted in 1895 by Giuseppe Peano after quoziente, Italian for "quotient", and first appeared in Bourbaki's Alg√®bre.[5]
